Award.AwardTitle: Defining a Role for GABAB Receptor Signaling in Activation of TORC1 Kinase During Homeostatic Plasticity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fluctuations in brain neuron activity promote learning and memory. If activity levels remain too high or too low for extended periods of time, the communication between neurons becomes unstable, and, as a consequence, new information cannot be learned. Neurons can alter which proteins are present at specialized sites called synapses, where signals are transmitted from one neuron to another. The way that neurons make these adjustments at the molecular level is poorly understood. Recent work has shown that a protein, referred to as GABAb receptor, causes new proteins to be synthesized by the neuron by a mechanism that involves a second protein, referred to as mTOR. This project will determine how GABAb receptors activate mTOR using cultured rat and mouse neurons. Cultured neurons are the system of choice for visualizing changes in protein synthesis at synapses. The project will determine if the GABAb receptor - mTOR interaction promotes changes in synapse number, which then lead to enhanced communication between neurons. The project will provide training for undergraduates, graduates, and postdoctoral students, including students who are underrepresented in science. It will support development of a new graduate course that trains incoming students in neuroscience laboratory techniques and that gives postdoctoral fellows a formal opportunity to build their teaching skills. Outreach activities are planned through a Community Education Program, Memory Matters.

In the brain, mTOR activity regulates protein synthesis, which is essential for learning and memory. Neurons remodel their synapses (plasticity), to accommodate dramatic changes in activity in order to facilitate new learning (homeostasis). One of the most striking examples of homeostatic plasticity is the formation of new synapses when N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) inputs are blocked, a mechanism thought to require protein synthesis. Recent work from the principal investigator's laboratory has discovered that during NMDAR blockade, GABAb receptors shift from activating post-synaptic potassium channels to increasing L-type calcium channel activity. The rise in calcium channel activity increases mTOR activity in dendrites. This project will use calcium and fluorescent imaging to define the mechanism that shifts GABAb receptor signaling to activate mTOR (Aim 1 and 2). The project will elucidate whether the functional shift of the GABAb receptor is required for structural changes in synapses and synapse number (Aim 3). The project will elucidate whether the functional shift of the GABAb receptor is required for structural changes in synapses and synapse number (Aim 3). This project will offer new insight into molecular mechanisms of homeostatic plasticity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Increased neuronal communications is critical for normal learning and memory and compromised in neurological disorders such as depression, Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Under normal conditions, homeostatic mechanisms are in place to ensure that the neuron operates in the optimal range. When neuronal communication is too little (e.g. approaching conditions that lead to depressive symptoms and/or cognitive decline) the neuron remodels its protein composition to push back. However, until recently, these mechanisms have been understudied and poorly defined. Thus, the overall goal of this Award was to study homeostatic mechanisms that increase the number of synapses, the site of communication between neurons. We made the novel finding that when communication between neurons is blocked or reduced, key proteins that usually restrain excessive communication (e.g. GABA, the major inhibitory transmitter) switch to increase communication by starting a chain of events that lead to new synaptic contacts between neurons. Through three Specific Aims we define each step of the chain of events including (1) how proteins that mediate inhibitory signals are removed from the membrane while (2) new protein synthesis promotes new receptors that increase calcium and postsynaptic protrusions (spines) on neuronal dendrites. This in turn leads to (3) a second wave of protein synthesis mediated by mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 which synthesizes a signal that engages the presynaptic cell (trans-synaptic signal) to form a new synapse. Collectively, these cellular events increase neuronal communication. By defining this mechanism step by step, this Award has produced significant outcomes: (1) We have identified a critical RNA-binding protein, Fragile X Mental Retardation protein (FMRP), required for the switch in GABA signaling and new synapse formation, (2) we have discovered that FMRP is required for mTORC1-mediated trans-synaptic signaling, and (3) importantly, this homeostatic mechanism relieves depressive-like symptoms via rapidly acting antidepressants, drugs that block neuronal activity through the N-methyl-D- aspartate receptor (NMDAR).

Broader Impacts:

The data generated by these studies have the intrinsic broader impact of discovering potential mechanism based treatments for major depressive disorder, thus potentially saving lives. In addition, these studies have broadened participation in Science in the following ways: First, they served as the basis for a new course called boot camp. New graduate students spent two weeks engaged in four different modules designed to expose them to multidisciplinary Neuroscience. The above research on homeostatic plasticity was incorporated into the molecular and behavioral module. Beyond basic graduate student education, this course provided postdoctoral fellows the opportunity to work with experienced Professors to design and teach short lecture and lab courses – providing valuable teaching experience without requiring a significant time away from the laboratory. As an example of how this course served as a multiplier for education, a Postdoctoral Fellow who is an underrepresented minority in Science, gained critical teaching experience and is now teaching at the historically minority institution, Winston-Salem State University.
